Info.title: Urban Traffic Flow Prediction Using LSTM and GRU

Abstract: For smart cities, the issue of how to solve traffic chaos has always attracted public attention. Many studies have proposed various solutions for traffic flow prediction, such as ARIMA, ANN, and SVM. With the breakthrough of deep learning technology, the evolutionary models of RNN, such as LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) and GRU (Gated Recurrent Units) models, have been proven to have excellent performance in traffic flow prediction. By using LSTM and GRU models, we explore more features and multi-layer models to increase the accuracy of traffic flow prediction. We compare the prediction accuracy of LSTM and GRU models in urban traffic flow prediction. The data collected in this study are divided into three categories, namely “regular traffic flow data”, “predictable episodic event data”, and “meteorological data”. The regular traffic flow data source is the “Vehicle Detector (VD) data of Taipei Open Data Platform”. Predictable episodic event data are predictable as non-routine events such as concerts and parades. We use a crawler program to collect this information through ticketing systems, tourism websites, news media, social media, and government websites and the meteorological data from the Central Meteorological Bureau. Through these three types of data, the accuracy in predicting traffic flow is enhanced to predict the degree of traffic congestion that may be affected.

General Computer Science.reason: The paper involves general concepts of computer science, such as algorithms and data structures, which are fundamental to the implementation and application of LSTM and GRU models.

Computer Science (miscellaneous).reason: This category serves as a catch-all for aspects of the paper that don't neatly fit into other, more specific categories. The application of deep learning models to a real-world problem like traffic flow prediction falls under this umbrella.

Artificial Intelligence.reason: The paper heavily relies on deep learning techniques, specifically LSTM and GRU, which are core components of AI and machine learning.

Computational Theory and Mathematics.reason: LSTM and GRU models are based on mathematical principles and computational theory. Understanding the underlying mathematics is crucial for developing and applying these models effectively.

Computer Graphics and Computer-Aided Des.reason: Not directly relevant. The paper doesn't discuss any aspect of computer graphics or CAD.

Computer Networks and Communications.reason: While traffic flow is related to networks, the paper doesn't focus on the communication aspects of computer networks. The focus is on prediction using machine learning.

Computer Science Applications.reason: The paper presents a specific application of computer science techniques (LSTM and GRU) to solve a real-world problem (urban traffic flow prediction).

Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition.reason: While traffic flow prediction can be seen as a pattern recognition problem, the paper doesn't explicitly use computer vision techniques. The data is time-series data, not image data.

Hardware and Architecture.reason: Not directly relevant. The paper doesn't discuss the hardware or architectural aspects of the computing systems used.

Human-Computer Interaction.reason: Not directly relevant. The paper doesn't focus on the interaction between humans and computers.

Information Systems.reason: The paper involves collecting, processing, and analyzing data from various sources (traffic sensors, websites, etc.) to build a predictive model, which is a core aspect of information systems.

Signal Processing.reason: Traffic flow data can be considered a time-series signal. Signal processing techniques might be used for pre-processing or feature extraction, although this is not explicitly mentioned.

Software.reason: The implementation of LSTM and GRU models requires software development. The crawler program mentioned in the abstract also falls under this domain.
